newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Cambodia tobacco output to double in 3-5 years.
newsitem.headline: Cambodia tobacco output to double in 3-5 years.

text.p: British American Tobacco officials said on Thursday that a pilot growing project in Cambodia indicated tobacco yields could be doubled within three to five years.
Mohammed Abdul Aleem, general manager of British American Tobacco Cambodia Ltd, also said low-priced Cambodian tobacco leaf could be developed into a $20 million export industry in 10 years.
Aleem made the comments at a farmer's day ceremony in this central Cambodian commune, where 50 farmers are testing new growing methods on 3,500 hectares (8,650 acres).
Currently tobacco yields average 685 kgs (1,510 pounds) per hectare each year with Cambodian farmers generating 8.9 million kgs (19.6 million pounds) of leaf annually in the $13.4 million industry.
Cambodia exports $5 million worth of leaf a year.
Aleem said yields could be doubled through the improved techniques used here and applied in 80 other countries.

Farmers in the commune are expected to increase yields some 600 kgs per hectare annually to 1,200-1,500 kgs per hectare through trimming plants, ridging the soil and using improved seed and curing methods.
"We are confident, based on the results so far, we can (double the yield)," Aleem told Reuters,
He expected those levels could be reached in three to five years, depending on the number of farmers using the new techniques.
Aleem Said BAT would negotiate more contracts with local farmers in the next year and was willing to supply all farmers with better seed to develop the Cambodian tobacco industry.
BAT Cambodia is a joint venture between British American Tobacco Holdings Ltd (51 percent), Cambodian businessmen Kong Triv (29 percent), and distributor Singapore United Trading Ltd (20 percent).
